{{lowercase}} {{Infobox software | name = win32-loader | screenshot = [[Image:Win32-loader.png|200px|Screenshot of win32-loader]] | caption = win32-loader fetching the Debian Installer under Windows Vista | developer = Robert Millan | latest release version = 0.6.10 | latest_release_date = {{release_date|2009|01|18}} | operating_system = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] 95 / 98 / 2000 / XP / Vista | status = | genre = [[Debian-Installer]] loader | license = [[GNU General Public License|GPL]] (version 3) | website = [http://goodbye-microsoft.com/ goodbye-microsoft.com] }} [[Image:Debian Installer screenshot.png|thumb|300px|The setup has been completed]] '''win32-loader''' is a component of the [[Debian-Installer]] that runs on [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] and has the ability to load the actual installer either from the network (as in the version used in [http://ftp.nl.debian.org/debian/tools/win32-loader/stable/win32-loader.exe http://ftp.nl.debian.org/debian/tools/win32-loader/stable/win32-loader.exe]) or from [[CD-ROM]] media (as in the version included in [[Debian#Releases|lenny]] CD images).
win32-loader was born as an independent project, for which only the network version was available. Later the code would go through a long review and polishing process to become part of the official [[Debian]] distribution.
== Influences == win32-loader strongly relies on projects such as [[Nullsoft Scriptable Install System|NSIS]], [[GNU GRUB|GRUB 2]], [[loadlin]] and [[Debian-Installer]] to perform its task. Additionally, it has drawn inspiration and ideas from similar projects such as [[Wubi (installer)|Wubi]] and [[Instlux]].
== Features == * Auto-detects 64-bit ([[x86-64]]) support in host CPUs, and automatically selects x86-64 flavor of Debian whenever supported, completely transparently to the user. * Detects a number of settings from Windows environment (timezone, proxy settings, etc) and feeds them to Debian Installer via ''preseeding'' mechanism so that user doesn't have to select them. * Translated to 28 languages. Selected language is displayed for user interaction since the first template, and is seamlessly passed on to Debian Installer via ''preseeding''.
